ai-ud1.2:1.2_0: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying near Uruvelā at the root of the tree of awakening on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.
ai-ud1.2:1.3_0: There the Buddha sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
ai-ud1.2:1.4_0: When seven days had passed, the Buddha emerged from that state of immersion. In the second part of the night, he reflected on dependent origination in reverse order:
ai-ud1.2:2.1_0: “When this doesn’t exist, that is not; due to the cessation of this, that ceases. That is:
ai-ud1.2:2.4_0: from the cessation of (volitional) processes, the cessation of consciousness,
ai-ud1.2:2.5_0: from the cessation of consciousness, the cessation of mind and bodily form,
ai-ud1.2:2.6_0: from the cessation of mind and bodily form, the cessation of the six sense spheres,
ai-ud1.2:2.7_0: from the cessation of the six sense spheres, the cessation of contact,
ai-ud1.2:2.9_0: from the cessation of feeling, the cessation of craving,
ai-ud1.2:2.10_0: from the cessation of craving, the cessation of attachment,
ai-ud1.2:2.11_0: with the cessation of attachment, the cessation of continuation,
ai-ud1.2:2.12_0: from the cessation of continuation, the cessation of birth,
ai-ud1.2:2.13_0: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.
ai-ud1.2:2.14_0: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”’”
ai-ud1.2:3.1_0: Then, knowing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ai-ud1.2:4.1_0: “When (the nature of) things becomes really manifest
ai-ud1.2:4.4_0: since he’s known the end of conditions.”
